We next force all the clients to participate in each round of training
and show the classification results in tableÂ 1.
We evaluate the performance of all the methods w.r.t. the weighted average accuracy, where the weights are proportional to the client sample sizes.
The accuracy is reported
with mean and standard deviation over three random runs.
From the table,
we see that FedCOMEÂ beats other competitors
on MNIST, CIFAR-10, and CIFAR-100.
While
FedCOMEÂ is not the winner on
FEMNIST,
it can still achieve comparable performance with the best result.
These observations show the effectiveness of
our method FedCOME,
which optimizes the global objective while ensuring decreased risks for all the clients after each iteration.

To further study model efficiency,
we plot the convergence curves of all the methods on all the datasets in FigureÂ 1.
From the figure,
we see that
FedCOME, FedDC and FedDyn are among the best three in terms of convergence speed.
While FedDC performs very well on MNIST and FEMNIST datasets,
it converges very slow on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100,
which shows its instability.
For FedCOMEÂ and FedDyn,
they have comparable convergence speeds.
For example,
both of them outperform other methods by a large margin
on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100.
However,
our method FedCOMEÂ can converge to higher accuracy values,
which are also clarified in TableÂ 1.
These results show that our method FedCOMEÂ is both effective and efficient.

To examine the robustness of FedCOMEÂ against varying degrees of data heterogeneity, we further conduct experiments on CIFAR-10 to simulate different degrees of heterogeneity.
We set
the number of classes Câˆˆ{2,3,4}ğ¶234C\in\{2,3,4\} that each client has at most.
The smaller Cğ¶C is, the fewer data overlap between clients and the stronger data heterogeneity among clients.
Experimental results are shown in TableÂ 2.
From the table,
we see that both FedCOMEÂ and FedDyn
outperform other methods
when meeting data heterogeneity.
Compared with FedDyn,
FedCOMEÂ performs better as data heterogeneity increases.
This shows the advantage of FedCOMEÂ in dealing with data heterogeneity.

To verify the effectiveness of our method in the partial participation FL scenario,
we run all the methods on CIFAR-10 with the same settings as in the full participation scenario.
We vary the participation ratio per round from {10%,20%,30%,40%}percent10percent20percent30percent40\{10\%,20\%,30\%,40\%\}.
For each method, we run two variants: one with our proposed client sampling strategy (shown in regular fonts) and the other with random sampling (shown in small fonts).
Experimental results are shown in TableÂ 3.
From the table,
we observe that:

We implement FedCOMEÂ using PyTorch and train it by SGD optimizer.
In our experiments,
the balancing coefficient Î±ğ›¼\alpha in Eq.Â 15 and the percentage Î¼ğœ‡\mu are set to 0.5 and 0.7, respectively.
For all the methods,
we set the local minibatch size to 50, weight decay to 1e-3 and learning rate to 0.05 with a learning rate decay of 0.998 per round.
Further,
clients are set to perform local optimization for five epochs on CIFAR-100 and one epoch on other datasets.
For all the baselines,
we perform grid search to fine-tune their hyper-parameters, whose
search space is
summarized in TableÂ 5 of Appendix.
We implement FedFV and FedDC with the official codes released by their authors
and use the codes released byÂ [9] for other baselines.
For each dataset,
we adopt the same neural network model for all the methods.
Specifically, we adopt a fully connected network with one hidden layer of 64 units on MNIST.
Similar as inÂ [28],
for CIFAR10, CIFAR-100 and FEMNIST,
we use a ConvNetÂ [17] that contains 2 convolutional layers and 2 fully connected layers.
All the experiments are run on one Tesla V100 GPU.
